repnme.cdata!:
Serbia and Montenegro - Financial Sector
            Development Technical Assistance Grant Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Financial Sector
            Development Technical Assistance Grant Project for Serbia
            and Montenegro were as follows: the outcome was highly
            satisfactory, the sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Lessons learned: the project design reflected best practice
            lessons from the Bank's prior operations in ECA,
            tailored to Serbian environment. Technical assistance in
            support of politically difficult transition reforms have a
            higher chance of success if designed as an integral part of
            Bank's broader sector assistance strategy. The
            implementation of a complex and politically sensitive
            Technical Assistance (TA) program does not only require a
            fully functioning implementing agency, but also constant
            support at the level of senior policy-making. The effective
            coordination by the Bank of technical assistance provided by
            bilateral donors can be a critical factor in quickly
            developing the institutional capacity to implement high
            impact reforms. Flexibility built into the TA operations is
            essential when dealing with rapidly evolving operational
            environment. Creating efficient institutional arrangements
            is a critical factor for implementing the complex technical
            assistance program.

5087624.trustfund:
TF029799-FRY - FINANCIAL SECTOR
            DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Yugoslavia, Federal Republic of - Financial
            Sector Development Technical Assistance Grant Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Sector Development
            Technical Assistance Grant Project supports the launch and
            implementation of a comprehensive bank resolution strategy.
            Specifically, the project supports the rehabilitation and
            rapid privatization of a limited number of large state
            banks; and the liquidation and divestitutre of all other
            insolvent banks that are not selected for restructuring.
            There are four project components. The first and second
            components fund technical assistance to 1) support the
            preparatory work to implement stabilization, rehabilitation,
            and pre-privatization efforts, particularly management and
            advisory services; and 2) pro-support rapid privatization on
            a case-by-case basis using investment banks and sales agents
            through providing consultant fees for the fixed fee
            component for an investment bank to undertake bank
            privatizations and fees for legal advisory services and
            support. The third component funds technical assistance to
            support rapid liquidation and work-out of all insolvent
            banks not selected for rehabilitation and stabilization
            programs. This support is in the form of management and
            advisory services and fees. The fourth component supports
            project implementation capacity.
